I have never been comfortable with the bathtub analogy for the reasons discussed here. Too many sinks, and it's too much of a "cycle" to be as static as a bathtub.

I am even more interested now as we begin to discuss heat transfer into the oceans as a possible factor in the slowing of surface temp increases. Once you are out of equilibrium, physics works to re-balance. Water is slow, air is fast. Is the same true for ocean CO2 absorption as Chris describes?

Another thought occurred, in a transition back to equilibrium, would climate effects be just as unpredictable (unstable?) as they are now? As well as the the consequent weather? In other words, would the weather be as weird or weirder as we ratchet back down in GHGs and heat?
